learningContent.title: Setting up source and output folders

lcInstruction.p: Once you have installed the DITA OT, the next step is setting up a folder structure for testing its publishing capabilities. Establishing folders for your DITA source files and published output files will help you avoid confusion and make the process of using the DITA OT run more smoothly.

conbody.p: When you’re working in a standalone DITA OT publishing environment, a well-organized folder structure helps you keep track of your DITA source content. Here are some best practices for setting up your source folders:

li.p: Don’t disrupt the DITA hierarchy. The way you store your DITA content in folders may interfere with the DITA OT’s ability to parse the content and generate some output types from it. Therefore, it is best to avoid storing a map file in a folder that lives below the topic files referenced in the map.
Mange your shared content. If you have topics that are referenced in multiple maps, keep them together in a folder (named something like “shared” or “reused”) where they are easy to find.

conbody.p: By default, the DITA Open Toolkit creates a default output folder named “out.” If you use the default “out” folder, be aware that the DITA OT replaces the previously generated output with new output each time you run the DITA OT on the same set of source content for the same type of output. For example, if you generated PDF output of b_ducks.ditamap yesterday and you generate PDF output of the same map today, yesterday’s PDF is deleted and today’s PDF replaces it. (If you generate PDF output from a different map, or generate HTML output from the same map, yesterday’s PDF remains in place.)
Here are some options for setting up your own output folders instead of using the default “out” folder:

li.p: Create output folders on your system. As with your DITA OT folder and source folders, make sure that the filepaths for your output folders do not contain any spaces or special characters. There are many ways you can organize your output folders, including:
It may help to keep all of your output folders under one main “output” or “testing” folder.

Create sub-folders in the default “out” folder. The DITA OT only generates output directly into the “out” folder by default, not into any sub-folders you add. Therefore, you can either tell the DITA OT to send your output into one of the subfolders, or allow the DITA OT to generate output into the default “out” folder and then move it into the correct sub-folder.

taskbody.context: Use these instructions to set up source and output folders on your system for testing.

step.cmd: Create a new folder on your machine and name it “sources.”
Locate the samples folder you downloaded at the beginning of this course.
Copy the “ducks” folder into the “sources” folder.
In the same location as your “sources” folder, create a new folder and name it “outputs.”
Inside the “outputs” folder, create a new folder and name it “ducks_output.”

taskbody.result: You are now ready to test the DITA OT.
